text:
As an undergrad myself, I never really understood why Bayesian approaches really stood out until one of my professors showed me how to update a Beta distribution based off of binary data; e.g. modeling credible intervals for the chance that a player will win a future match of a game given a history of their wins and losses in comparable circumstances.

That simple example really made Bayesian concepts sort of "click" for me. I'd seen the Beta distribution before too, but had very little understanding of why the parameters did what they did. I'd also heard explanations of Bayesian  analysis before, but I also didn't really quite understand what made the approach interesting.

As an undergrad myself, I never really understood why Bayesian approaches really stood out until one of my professors showed me how to update a Beta distribution based off of binary data; e.g. modeling credible intervals for the chance that a player will win a future match of a game given a history of their wins and losses in comparable circumstances.

That simple example really made Bayesian concepts sort of "click" for me. I'd seen the Beta distribution before too, but had very little understanding of why the parameters did what they did. I'd also heard explanations of Bayesian  analysis before, but I also didn't really quite understand what made the approach interesting.

text:
In my case, I had a use case where I wanted a method to estimate both a win chance for a player and some sort of measurement of uncertainty on that, ideally with a nice analytical form. I asked my professor for help and I've fallen in love with Bayesian methods since then.

Bayesian updating with the Beta distribution is probably my favorite example of Bayesian techniques, as it's a really elegant and beautiful example. I feel like showing the method in which a Beta distribution can be updated using binary data is almost like a Bayesian equivalent to showing students the nice properties of Normal distributions in their first introduction to statistics.

The most common Beta distribution parameters looked like total nonsense to me until I saw them used in a Bayesian context.
